Award.AwardTitle: Resources to Implement Flipped Chemical Engineering Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing curriculum materials for two chemical engineering core courses: thermodynamics and material and energy balances. These materials are promoting active learning, which has been shown to increase student learning, by reducing the barriers encountered by faculty who want to use more effective teaching approaches. An essential element is a set of explanations of the underlying theories for these teaching approaches and links to additional references.

This project is providing resources for flipped classrooms, in which students are watching screencasts (short videos with narration) on their own before class. Class time is being used for more active engagement with the material, which is resulting in better learning of conceptually difficult material. Resources for faculty also include a complete set of class notes that utilize active learning (ConcepTests with peer instruction, in-class group exercises, etc.), measureable learning objectives for each class period, a database of solved example problems, homework assignments, and exams. They are organized in OneNote software so they can be easily modified and customized to individual faculty.

Program evaluation is measuring the utilization of the materials and how faculty change their educational approach. These materials are being made available online, accompanied by screencasts that describe how to use them. Dissemination of these materials is enhancing the STEM education community and providing faculty professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A complete set of course notes, referred to as a course package, was developed for chemical engineering thermodynamics and material and energy balances. These are two required courses that are likely to be taught by new faculty, and one objective of this project was to make it easier for new faculty to incorporate evidence-based learning into chemical engineering courses and thus improve student learning.  These course packages contains complete notes for use in class, instructor explanations, ConcepTests (conceptual questions with answers and explanations), reading quizzes, homework assignments, exams, links to screencasts, and educational resources sufficient to instruct the entire course with an extensive focus on active learning. The course packages are fully integrated with an extensive suite of additional ConcepTests and screencasts. Direct hyperlinks for screencasts can be used in flipped lessons, where information delivery is outside the classroom and active learning exercises are used in class. These materials are disseminated on www.LearnChemE.com , and all users (475) of our site were solicited for interest in the course package.  An article was published in the journal Chemical Engineering Education, and talks have been presented at national meetings. Faculty have used the thermodynamics course package and 47 faculty have requested access to the thermodynamics package.
